item.title: Staying in a remote East Ugandan Village, Africa
item.description: “Is it true that women will be burnt alive for dowry in India?” Mai asked with her fear in her eyes and her palm covering her mouth. She did not mean to offend me. The innocence in her voice and her genuine concern for her sisters in India made me offer a simple, plain answer. “Yes, it does happen even now in some villages, although it is not legal” I tried to calm her down.

item.title: My adventures with Matatus
item.description: Before travelling to East Africa, I had managed my travels with two grand assumptions (a) long distances are better covered by night (b) if you are ready to pay a price, there are better options in public transport. While these two were busted pretty quickly, none of my experiences so far had prepared me for a “matatu”. From whatever I had read earlier, before landing in Kenya, I had deduced that all my travels had to be done during the day.

item.title: An unforgettable encounter with our closest cousin
item.description: It is unmistakably the most beautiful place we would be staying in our entire trip. I could spend hours just looking at these mountains, the rainforests and never cease to be amazed by their existence, being drawn into them further and further with every passing moment. I could be lost momentarily in mundane tasks like eating or washing clothes or fussing about the ants; but the presence of the mountains constantly pulls me into a trance every now and then.
